definitions.definition: connected with principles of right and wrong behaviour

examples.text: a **moral issue/dilemma**
traditional moral values
a decline in **moral standards**
moral and ethical questions
The basic moral philosophies of most world religions are remarkably similar.
He was a deeply religious man with a highly developed moral sense.
The newspapers were full of **moral outrage** at the weakness of other countries.
She's always lamenting what she sees as the decline in moral standards.
The colonel stumped out, his face flushed with moral indignation.
The press whipped up a moral panic over these so-called ‘welfare scroungers’.

definitions.definition: based on your own sense of what is right and fair, not on legal rights or duties

examples.text: **moral responsibility/duty/authority**
We have a **moral imperative **to help whenever we can.
I make no **moral judgement** on this decision.
Governments have at least a **moral obligation** to answer these questions.
Children learn to develop their own **moral code **for adulthood.
The job was to call on all her diplomatic skills and **moral courage** *(= the courage to do what you think is right)*.
He brings that moral authority of someone who fought for human rights.
Politicians have a moral obligation to address the needs of the poorest.
She felt she had a moral duty to speak out about injustice.

definitions.definition: following the standards of behaviour considered acceptable and right by most people

examples.text: He led a very moral life.
a very moral person
We try to teach our students to be conscientious, moral young people.

definitions.definition: able to understand the difference between right and wrong

examples.text: Children are not naturally moral beings.

definitions.definition: to claim that your side of an argument is morally better than your opponents’ side; to argue in a way that makes your side seem morally better

examples.text: I was angry with his blatant attempt to take the moral high ground.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Latin moralis, from mos, mor- ‘custom’, (plural) mores ‘morals’. As a noun the word was first used to translate Latin Moralia, the title of St Gregory the Great's moral exposition of the Book of Job, and was later applied to the works of various classical writers.
